original_data.question: A 16-year-old teenager presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe pain in his right knee. He describes the pain as the worst pain he has ever felt. He denies any recent trauma or injury to the knee. The joint appears red and swollen and is hot to the touch. He denies any lower extremity numbness. There is no family history of joint or connective tissue disorders. The teenager is otherwise healthy. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg, respirations are 17/min, pulse is 104/min, and temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). On palpation of the affected joint, there is evidence of tenderness and capsular swelling; the joint is red and warm. Laboratory studies show increased serum CRP and procalcitonin levels. Which of the following will most likely found with analysis of his synovial fluid?

model_response:
The synovial fluid analysis shows a high level of neutrophils, indicating an acute inflammatory process. The high level of neutrophils (> 75%) indicates a bacterial infection. The low viscosity indicates the fluid is not too thick or too thin. The most likely diagnosis is septic arthritis. The next step is to determine the offending organism.

Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person 13 to 18 years of age.
Hospital department responsible for the administration and provision of immediate medical or surgical care to the emergency patient.
Score 6-7
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
A question about an individual's pain at its worst.
A question about whether an individual feels or has felt tense.
Damage inflicted on the body as the direct or indirect result of an external force, with or without disruption of structural continuity.
Disorder resulting from physical damage to the body
A region of the lower extremity immediately surrounding and including the KNEE JOINT.
Also known as articulations, these are points of connection between the ends of certain separate bones, or where the borders of other bones are juxtaposed.
Enlargement; expansion in size; sign of inflammation
Placing of the hands of the healer upon the person to be cured with the intent of spiritual energetic healing.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions.

A heterogeneous group of disorders, some hereditary, others acquired, characterized by abnormal structure or function of one or more of the elements of connective tissue, i.e., collagen, elastin, or the mucopolysaccharides.
A person 13 to 18 years of age.
Having no significant health-related issues.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
Application of fingers with light pressure to the surface of the body to determine consistence of parts beneath in physical diagnosis; includes palpation for determining the outlines of organs.
To be influenced by or changed.
Knowledge on which to base belief.
A dull achy pain.
Also known as articulations, these are points of connection between the ends of certain separate bones, or where the borders of other bones are juxtaposed.
The clear portion of BLOOD that is left after BLOOD COAGULATION to remove BLOOD CELLS and clotting proteins.

A peptide prohormone precursor of CALCITONIN. It is normally present at low levels in serum, but is released into the bloodstream, primarily from neuroendocrine cells in the lungs and intestines, in response to INFLAMMATION and BACTERIAL INFECTIONS. It is a diagnostic marker for BACTEREMIA.
A position on a scale measuring intensity, quality, or amount.
The clear, viscous fluid secreted by the SYNOVIAL MEMBRANE. It contains mucin, albumin, fat, and mineral salts and serves to lubricate joints.
